citations.narrative:
There are several areas in need of repair at the facility. In an enclosure, housing two Bennett’s Wallabies, a back wall of a
barn has peeling and flaking paint that is falling directly into their enclosure. Additionally, a plastic corner molding of their
shelter is cracked and has created sharp edges. In the Capybara enclosure, there is also a section of plastic corner
molding that has cracked and exposed sharp edges. Wooden molding around a door has rotted and is falling apart,
leaving jagged edges.
Sharp edges can cause injury to the animals and ingestion of paint chips could be detrimental to the animal’s health.
Correct by ensuring the facilities shall are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from
injury and to contain the animals.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Directly behind the Emu and Kookaburra enclosures there is a storage area for the facility that has an excessive
accumulation of construction materials, supplies not in use, and discarded material which has led to overgrown
vegetation. The supplies obscure visualization of the ground and surrounding area, creating harborage areas for pests,
and prevent the facility and grounds from being properly maintained. Accumulations of material that provide safe areas for
pests and rodents can overwhelm the facility’s pest control program and compromise the health and well-being of the
birds.
Correct by ensuring premises where housing facilities are located, including buildings, surrounding grounds, and exhibit
areas, are kept clean and in good repair to protect the birds from injury and disease, to facilitate the husbandry practices
required in this subpart and to reduce or eliminate breeding and living areas for rodents, pests, and vermin. Premises
must be kept free of accumulations of trash, junk, waste products, and discarded matter. Weeds, grasses, and bushes
must be controlled to facilitate cleaning of the premises and pest control, and to protect the health and well-being of birds.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B" license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by Sept. 16th, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
Robert Ferguson, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Mary Ann Archer, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
There are several areas in need of repair at the facility. In an enclosure, housing two Bennett’s Wallabies, a back wall of a 
barn has peeling and flaking paint that is falling directly into their enclosure. Additionally, a plastic corner molding of their 
shelter is cracked and has created sharp edges. In the Capybara enclosure, there is also a section of plastic corner 
molding that has cracked and exposed sharp edges. Wooden molding around a door has rotted and is falling apart, 
leaving jagged edges.  
Sharp edges can cause injury to the animals and ingestion of paint chips could be detrimental to the animal’s health. 
Correct by ensuring the facilities shall are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from 
injury and to contain the animals. 
3.158(c) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Directly behind the Emu and Kookaburra enclosures there is a storage area for the facility that has an excessive 
accumulation of construction materials, supplies not in use, and discarded material which has led to overgrown 
vegetation. The supplies obscure visualization of the ground and surrounding area, creating harborage areas for pests, 
and prevent the facility and grounds from being properly maintained. Accumulations of material that provide safe areas for 
pests and rodents can overwhelm the facility’s pest control program and compromise the health and well-being of the 
birds.  
Correct by ensuring premises where housing facilities are located, including buildings, surrounding grounds, and exhibit 
areas, are kept clean and in good repair to protect the birds from injury and disease, to facilitate the husbandry practices 
required in this subpart and to reduce or eliminate breeding and living areas for rodents, pests, and vermin. Premises 
must be kept free of accumulations of trash, junk, waste products, and discarded matter. Weeds, grasses, and bushes 
must be controlled to facilitate cleaning of the premises and pest control, and to protect the health and well-being of birds. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B" license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by Sept. 16th, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license

fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Robert Ferguson, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Mary Ann Archer, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
